How to Cite Journal of Health and Social Behavior in APA Format

Complete guide to citing Journal of Health and Social Behavior in APA 7th edition with examples, unique formatting requirements, and common issues specific to this source.

Journal of Health and Social Behavior presents unique citation challenges that require specific guidance beyond general source type rules. This page provides targeted help for finding citation information, handling Journal of Health and Social Behavior's particular format requirements, and avoiding common mistakes specific to this platform.

üîç Try It Out

Paste a citation to check its Journal of Health and Social Behavior formatting

Quick Reference: Journal of Health and Social Behavior Citations

Reference List Format:
Author, A. A., & Author, B. B. (Year). Title of article. Title of Journal, volume(issue), pages. https://doi.org/xxxxx

Journal of Health and Social Behavior-Specific Notes:
When citing articles from the Journal of Health and Social Behavior (JHSB), it is crucial to adhere to both the journal's specific formatting requirements and the guidelines outlined in the APA 7th edition. While JHSB follows APA style, a unique aspect is its emphasis on detailed author attribution, particularly in extensive collaborative works. APA typically prescribes listing up to 20 authors by their last name and initials. JHSB adheres to this, ensuring all authors are acknowledged, which can be particularly nuanced when dealing with large-scale studies common in health and social behavior fields.

A notable difference in JHSB citations compared to standard APA rules is the journal's preference for more detailed author identification, sometimes requesting additional initials if authors share common surnames. This can cause confusion for students who may not be accustomed to verifying such details. Additionally, the journal might require expanded author lists even if APA's "et al." could suffice after the 20th author in a standard reference.

To avoid common mistakes, students should carefully check the author list against the publication's author affiliations and ensure all contributing authors are correctly cited. It's beneficial to use citation management tools that allow for customization to accommodate JHSB's specific needs. Furthermore, always refer directly to the journal‚Äôs submission guidelines, as they may have particular instructions for manuscript preparation that influence citation formatting. This diligence ensures accuracy and adherence to both APA standards and the journal's unique requirements.

In-Text Citation:
- Parenthetical: ([Author], [Year])
- Narrative: [Author] ([Year])

Key Points:
- Use Journal Article format with Journal of Health and Social Behavior specifics
- Locate citation info on Journal of Health and Social Behavior's website
- Handle Journal of Health and Social Behavior's unique formatting requirements

Where to Find Citation Information on Journal of Health and Social Behavior

To effectively locate citation information on the Journal of Health and Social Behavior website, follow these detailed steps. This guide will help you find the author, publication date, article title, and URL/access information for citing your sources accurately.

  1. Finding the Author(s):
    When you access an article on the Journal of Health and Social Behavior website, the author byline is prominently displayed at the top of the article page. Look for the section just below the article title where the authors' names are listed. The names are typically hyperlinked, which can lead you to additional information about the author(s) if needed.

  2. Identifying the Publication Date:
    The publication date is usually located just beneath the author byline. On the Journal of Health and Social Behavior site, this is often formatted as "First Published" or "Published Online," followed by the month, day, and year. This information is crucial for your citation as it indicates when the article was made publicly available.

  3. Locating the Article Title:
    The article title is prominently featured at the top of the page. It is typically in a larger font size than the rest of the text. Ensure you capture the full title as it appears, including any subtitles, as this will be essential for your citation.

  4. Accessing the URL:
    The URL or web address is found in your browser's address bar. This is the unique link that directs you to the specific article page on the Journal of Health and Social Behavior website. When citing an online article, it is important to include the complete URL to enable others to access the same source.

  5. Navigating the Journal's Site for Additional Information:
    If you need more detailed publication information, scroll down to the bottom of the article page. Here, you may find additional details like the volume, issue number, and page range, which are occasionally listed under a section titled "Article Information" or similar. This can be particularly helpful for constructing a complete reference.

By following these steps, you can efficiently gather the necessary citation information for articles from the Journal of Health and Social Behavior. Remember, accurate citations contribute to the credibility and traceability of your academic work. Always double-check the information for accuracy and completeness before including it in your references.

Step-by-Step: Creating Your Journal of Health and Social Behavior Citation

Creating a Citation for the Journal of Health and Social Behavior

Citing articles correctly is essential for academic writing. This guide will walk you through the step-by-step process to create a citation for an article from the Journal of Health and Social Behavior, following the APA citation style.

What You Need

  • Access to the article you want to cite
  • Basic details about the article: authors, year of publication, article title, journal name, volume number, issue number, and page numbers
  • A computer with internet access for research
  • A citation management tool (optional, but helpful)

Step-by-Step Instructions

  1. Identify the Article Details
    - Action: Locate the article you wish to cite. Ensure you have the following information: author(s), year of publication, title of the article, journal title, volume number, issue number, and page numbers.
    - Verification: Check that all details are accurate and complete. You can find this information on the article‚Äôs webpage or the PDF version.
    - Time Estimate: 5-10 minutes.
    - Tip: If you are searching online, using the title of the article in quotes can help you find it quickly.

  2. Format the Author‚Äôs Names
    - Action: Write the authors‚Äô names in the format: Last Name, First Initial. For multiple authors, separate them with commas, using an ampersand (&) before the last author.
    - Verification: Ensure that the names are formatted correctly, with the last name followed by the first initial and a period.
    - Time Estimate: 5 minutes.
    - Tip: Use a consistent format. For example, if you have three authors: Smith, J. A., & Doe, R. B.

  3. Add the Year of Publication
    - Action: After the authors' names, add the publication year in parentheses followed by a period.
    - Verification: Confirm that the year is the correct one from the article you are citing.
    - Time Estimate: 2 minutes.
    - Tip: Always check the article itself or the website to ensure accuracy.

  4. Write the Title of the Article
    - Action: Next, write the title of the article in sentence case. Only the first word of the title, the first word of the subtitle (if applicable), and proper nouns should be capitalized. Do not italicize or use quotation marks for the title.
    - Verification: Make sure the title is exactly as it appears in the article.
    - Time Estimate: 5 minutes.
    - Tip: Typing the title directly from the article helps avoid errors.

  5. Include the Journal Title, Volume, and Issue
    - Action: Write the journal title in italics, followed by a comma. Then, include the volume number in italics, followed by the issue number in parentheses (not italicized), and a comma. Finally, list the page range of the article.
    - Verification: Ensure that the volume and issue numbers are correct and formatted properly.
    - Time Estimate: 5 minutes.
    - Tip: You can often find the volume and issue numbers on the article‚Äôs webpage or in the PDF.

  6. Add the DOI Link
    - Action: At the end of the citation, include the DOI (Digital Object Identifier) in the format: https://doi.org/xxxxx. This should be a direct link to the article.
    - Verification: Ensure that the DOI is correct by checking the article's information or the publishing journal‚Äôs website.
    - Time Estimate: 3 minutes.
    - Tip: Copy and paste the DOI directly to avoid typos.

  7. Assemble the Citation
    - Action: Combine all the information you have gathered and formatted into a single citation. The format should look like this: Author, A. A., & Author, B. B. (Year). Title of article. Title of Journal, volume(issue), pages. https://doi.org/xxxxx.
    - Verification: Double-check each part of the citation for accuracy and correct formatting.
    - Time Estimate: 5 minutes.
    - Tip: Use a word processor with spell check to catch any typos.

  8. Review and Finalize
    - Action: Read through your complete citation one final time. Ensure that it follows APA style guidelines.
    - Verification: You can use an APA citation guide or online citation tool to compare your citation for accuracy.
    - Time Estimate: 5 minutes.
    - Tip: If you are using a citation management tool, this step

Real Examples from Journal of Health and Social Behavior

This section provides authentic citation examples from Journal of Health and Social Behavior using recent publications from 2023-2024.

I'm unable to browse the internet or access specific journal databases to retrieve current articles. However, I can guide you on how to format citations in APA 7th edition style once you have the necessary information. Here's how you can create citations using the structure you've provided, along with hypothetical examples:

  1. Standard Individual Author

  • Scenario Description: This is a standard research article authored by a single individual examining the relationship between social behavior and health outcomes.

  • Reference List Citation:
    Smith, J. A. (2023). The impact of social networks on health behaviors. *Journal of Health and Social Behavior, 64*(2), 123-134. https://doi.org/10.1177/1234567890123456

  • In-text Citation (Parenthetical):
    (Smith, 2023)

  • In-text Citation (Narrative):
    Smith (2023) discusses the impact of social networks on health behaviors.

  • Notes: This example is noteworthy for its exploration of modern social networks and their influence on individual health behavior, a topic of increasing relevance in digital society.

  1. Corporate Author

  • Scenario Description: A policy brief by a health organization analyzing the effects of public health interventions on community well-being.

  • Reference List Citation:
    World Health Organization. (2023). Public health interventions and community well-being. *Journal of Health and Social Behavior, 64*(2), 135-145. https://doi.org/10.1177/2345678901234567

  • In-text Citation (Parenthetical):
    (World Health Organization, 2023)

  • In-text Citation (Narrative):
    According to the World Health Organization (2023), public health interventions significantly impact community well-being.

  • Notes: This is an example of a corporate author, which is common in articles discussing large-scale health policies and interventions.

  1. Multiple Authors

  • Scenario Description: A collaborative study by multiple researchers on the psychosocial determinants of health.

  • Reference List Citation:
    Johnson, L. M., Nguyen, T. P., & Evans, R. J. (2023). Psychosocial determinants of health in urban populations. *Journal of Health and Social Behavior, 64*(3), 200-215. https://doi.org/10.1177/3456789012345678

  • In-text Citation (Parenthetical):
    (Johnson, Nguyen, & Evans, 2023)

  • In-text Citation (Narrative):
    Johnson, Nguyen, and Evans (2023) explore the psychosocial determinants of health.

  • Notes: This article is a good example of collaborative research, showcasing the diverse expertise brought together to address complex health issues.

  1. Special Formatting Cases

  • Scenario Description: An editorial piece reflecting on the journal‚Äôs contributions to health sociology over the past decade.

  • Reference List Citation:
    Miller, S. R. (2023). Reflecting on a decade of health sociology. *Journal of Health and Social Behavior, 64*(4), 250-252. https://doi.org/10.1177/4567890123456789

  • In-text Citation (Parenthetical):
    (Miller, 2023)

  • In-text Citation (Narrative):
    In his editorial, Miller (2023) reflects on the journal‚Äôs contributions to health sociology.

  • Notes: Editorials often provide unique insights or retrospectives and may not follow standard research article formats, making them interesting for context and commentary.

These examples should help you format citations appropriately once you have access to the actual articles. Remember to replace the hypothetical authors, titles, and DOIs with real information from the journal.

Common Issues When Citing Journal of Health and Social Behavior

Certainly! Citing academic journals correctly can be challenging, and the Journal of Health and Social Behavior (JHSB) presents specific issues that students often encounter. Below are common citation problems that students face with JHSB, along with solutions guided by APA 7th edition guidelines.

Finding Authors

Issue Description:
Students often struggle to correctly identify and format the authors of articles from JHSB. This challenge may stem from multiple authors or unconventional name formats.

Why It Happens:
JHSB articles can have multiple authors, and the author names might be presented differently on the journal's website compared to other databases. Additionally, for articles with more than 20 authors, APA 7th edition guidelines require a specific listing format.

Solution:
1. Identify all authors listed in the article. Use the "Cite" tool or look directly at the article‚Äôs first page for accurate author names.
2. List up to 20 authors in your reference. For articles with more than 20 authors, list the first 19 followed by an ellipsis (‚Ä¶) and then the final author's name.

Example:
- Before: Smith, J., Johnson, A., et al.
- After: Smith, J., Johnson, A., Brown, B., ‚Ä¶ Williams, Z.

Date Formats

Issue Description:
Inconsistent date formats can lead to improper citation, especially when students are unsure whether to use the article's publication date or the online posting date.

Why It Happens:
JHSB may publish articles online ahead of print, leading to confusion about which date to use.

Solution:
1. Use the publication date listed at the top of the article or in the citation information section. If the article is only available online as a preprint, use the online publication date.
2. Format the date as Year, Month Day if available.

Example:
- Before: (2023)
- After: (2023, March 15)

URL Handling

Issue Description:
Properly formatting and using URLs in citations can be challenging, particularly with URLs that change or are lengthy.

Why It Happens:
JHSB articles accessed through databases might have URLs that are session-based or temporary, leading to broken links.

Solution:
1. Use the DOI (Digital Object Identifier) if available instead of a URL. The DOI provides a permanent link to the article.
2. Place the DOI at the end of the citation in the format: https://doi.org/xxxx

Example:
- Before: Retrieved from http://www.jstor.org/stable/xyz
- After: https://doi.org/10.1177/00221465231111111

Access Requirements

Issue Description:
Students often face issues accessing JHSB articles, leading to incomplete or incorrect citations.

Why It Happens:
JHSB may require a subscription or institutional access, causing students to rely on summaries or incomplete information.

Solution:
1. Access through a university library portal or request the article through interlibrary loan if direct access is unavailable.
2. Always verify citation details using the full article text.

Example:
- Before: Citing from an abstract or secondary source.
- After: Citing directly from the article: "Smith, J. (2023). Title of article. Journal of Health and Social Behavior, 64(1), 10-20. https://doi.org/10.1177/00221465231111111"

By addressing these issues methodically, students can ensure accurate and complete citations for their academic work, adhering to APA 7th edition guidelines and respecting the unique challenges posed by the Journal of Health and Social Behavior.

Note: For general Journal Article citation errors, see How to Cite Journal Article.

Frequently Asked Questions About Journal of Health and Social Behavior

Q: How can I locate the citation information for articles from the Journal of Health and Social Behavior on their website?

A: On the Journal of Health and Social Behavior's website, navigate to the article's page. The citation information, including author names, publication year, article title, and DOI, is typically available at the top or in the metadata section of the article page.

Q: How should I handle author names when citing articles with multiple authors from the Journal of Health and Social Behavior?

A: For articles with up to 20 authors, list all author names in your reference. Use an ampersand (&) before the last author's name. For 21 or more authors, list the first 19 authors, insert an ellipsis, and then add the final author's name.

Q: What is the correct way to format the publication date for articles from the Journal of Health and Social Behavior?

A: In APA format, the publication year is placed in parentheses immediately after the author's name(s) in the reference list. The Journal of Health and Social Behavior often provides the month or season of publication, but only the year is necessary for the citation.

Q: Do I need to include a URL or DOI when citing an article from the Journal of Health and Social Behavior?

A: Always include the DOI in your citation if it is available, as it provides a permanent link to the article. If no DOI is available, you may include the URL of the journal's homepage if it is an online-only article.

Q: How does citing an article from the Journal of Health and Social Behavior differ from citing other journal articles in APA style?

A: Citing articles from the Journal of Health and Social Behavior follows the same APA guidelines as other journals, with special attention to the DOI. The main difference is ensuring you accurately capture the journal's specific author formatting and publication details, as outlined by the journal itself.
